Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YMED1001 - Introduction to Population Health","description":"

This course, offered by Arizona State University under the PLuS Alliance, serves as an introduction to the basic principles in community and public health, core functions of public health, role of government and non-government agencies, and health policies affecting populations. It also emphasizes primary, secondary, and tertiary levels of prevention related to health problems/diseases, and highlights social, cultural and behavioural factors that influence health. The course focuses on populations in the United States as well as drawing international comparisons on public health issues.


This YMED1001 course serves as an important complement to the YMED1008 Introduction to Global Health course. The latter addresses health around the world, highlighting the critical role of transdisciplinary approaches and social perspectives in tackling major health challenges. These courses use contemporary research evidence and practice relating to population and public health.

There will be 10 homework tasks each worth 3%. Each task involves answering questions posted on Blackboard based on assigned textbook readings or viewings of short videos.

In order to support students in their academic success while providing them with appropriate writing tools and resources, all students are required to view a PowerPoint and complete a quiz on Academic Integrity. 

To provide proof of understanding of the Academic Integrity policy, students must complete the quiz with an 80% or higher pass rate by the due date in the course schedule. It is a mandatory requirement in this class and without successful completion of this quiz, no other assignments or materials will be graded for course credit.

ASU Student Academic Integrity Policy   http://www.asu.edu/studentaffairs/studentlife/judicial/academic_integrity.htm

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e3f16010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961984","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"73f16010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396199e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exams","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

There will be four exams, each worth 10%. Each exam will cover the course content covered in lectures, readings and other materials in the previous weeks preceding the exam.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e3f16010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"e3f16010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e3f16010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961984","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"e3f16010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e3f16010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"ebf16010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ebf16010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ebf16010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961984","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ebf16010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"ebf16010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961986","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"88026010dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ab","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

The final presentation is a group assignment. Each group will be allocated a project topic, and the group must interview a representative from a relevant organisation. The assessment consists of three components submitted in stages: interview questions for the presentation (5%), detailed outline of the presentation (10%), and the final presentation (10%).

Students will be asked to share what each team member contributed to the final project. Students who do not participate or contribute to their team’s final projects (an outline and presentation) will receive a 0 for those grades. 

Rubrics will provide students with explicit and descriptive assignment grading criteria. They will reflect the weighted importance of the assignment components.

Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YMED1002 - College Mathematics","description":"

This course is designed to strengthen the student's foundation in quantitative reasoning and understanding of basic math, elementary algebra, sets, probability, statistics, finance, and geometry. In teaching these concepts, the course emphasizes problem-solving techniques. Students will apply basic college-level mathematics to real-life problems. Representative examples are used to illustrate important and general key concepts.


This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a002a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961938","name":"Fully online - "},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Problem Solving","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will complete one written problem for each lesson. Each problem will be available on Blackboard under the Problem Solving link in the left course menu. Each problem must be completed and returned no later than by 11:59 pm MST on the deadline given in the schedule below. Students must write the solution and explanation to each problem. Students will submit each solution using the appropriate assignment in Blackboard. Students should scan their solution or take a picture of them and submit that image. All submissions must be in pdf file format. Students will need to make sure that their name and the date are on each page of the problem set.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2402a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2402a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396193a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2c02a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2c02a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2c02a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396193a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a002a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396194a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Each exam has an exam review. Each exam review is recommended to be completed prior to taking the exam. There is no credit for completing the exam reviews. It is required that students open the exam review and correctly answer enough questions to get a score of 1% prior to the related exam becoming available. This must be done before they start an exam.

Students will take five unit exams during the semester. Each exam will involve a mix of mechanical skills and conceptual reasoning. Each student will only get a single attempt at each unit exam. Once students put in the exam password, their attempt has started and must be completed in 60 minutes. No exam scores will be
dropped.


ALL EXAMS MUST BE PROCTORED.
Students must take a proctored exam using RPNow by Software Secure (http://www.softwaresecure.com). ASU will bear the exam cost. The student will make all arrangements and a web cam is required.

Any student who accesses a phone or any internet-capable device during an exam for any reason automatically receives a score of zero on the exam. All such devices must be turned off and put away and made inaccessible during the exam. Anyone using a camera device, other than the webcam, for any reason during an online assessment will receive a score of 0 for that exam, and possible further disciplinary measures.
If any student does not pass the RPNow's verification process during an exam and does not have photo on record in ASU's system, then their test result will remain a 0 until that student uploads an image so that we can compare to RPNow's incident report they send us.

contentlets.description:
This course is designed to strengthen the student's foundation in quantitative reasoning and understanding of basic math, elementary algebra, sets, probability, statistics, finance, and geometry. In teaching these concepts, the course emphasizes problem-solving techniques. Students will apply basic college-level mathematics to real-life problems. Representative examples are used to illustrate important and general key concepts.

This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.

The course covers the topics of cell biology, molecular biology, metabolism, and physiology of selected tissue and organ systems. Students who successfully complete this course will have an appreciation for the complexities of biological structure and function. This course serves as a gateway to more advanced courses in the life sciences biology, and health-related science majors by introducing students to major concepts and theories of biology. The course is also valuable for students preparing to take admissions tests for medical, dental, or veterinary medical schools.

The lab portion of the course will contain 2 case studies and 5 laboratory simulations.  Grades for this portion of the class will come from 1) the discussions of the case students posted in blackboard, 2) Answers to specific questions concerning both the a) case studies and b) laboratory exercises, completion of the lab simulation each of which has its own questions associated with it.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c102a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"c102a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c102a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c902a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"c902a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c902a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c902a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8502a010dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lectures","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"75","description":"

The video lectures will present the topics that the a) Self Checks, b) Quizzes and c) Exam are based on.  The Self-Checks will be given at the end of each lecture segment and will have not have a point value.  The Lecture portion of the course will be graded based on the 3 Exams and 4 Quizzes and these will be developed from the video lectures and the Self Checks.   Relevant pages from the textbook will be listed to aid students understanding if something in the video lecture confuses them.

contentlets.keywords: asu medicine,biology,structure and function,molecular,cellular and organismal level,life science,cell biology,molecular biology,metabolism,physiology,tissue and organ systems
contentlets.description: The course covers the topics of cell biology, molecular biology, metabolism, and physiology of selected tissue and organ systems. Students who successfully complete this course will have an appreciation for the complexities of biological structure and function. This course serves as a gateway to more advanced courses in the life sciences biology, and health-related science majors by introducing students to major concepts and theories of biology. The course is also valuable for students preparing to take admissions tests for medical, dental, or veterinary medical schools.
contentlets.title: General Biology

UNSW students enrol in this course at the relevant PLuS Alliance partner university. Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YMED1004 - Human Anatomy and Physiology 1","description":"

This course covers the study of the structure and function of the human body. Topics including Surface Anatomy, Chemistry, Cells, Genetics, Histology, Integumentary System, Skeletal System, Joints, Muscular System, Central/Peripheral/Autonomic Nervous Systems and Sense Organs. To enhance understanding of concepts, activities used for instruction and assessment of learning include: discussion/presentations; textbook and supplemental readings; individual and group activities/assignments; hands-on dissections and case scenarios. This course also provides valuable professional skills such as laboratory skills, problem-solving, working as part of a team and research and presentation skills. As such, this course prepares students for a wide range of opportunities in public health including: teaching, science communication, exercise physiology, medical sales and health research as a research assistant.


This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6102e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961929","name":"Fully online - "},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lecture exams","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

There are four lecture exams structured throughout the course with each exam worth 100 points (4 x 100 points = 400 points total representing a weighting of 40% (400/1000)).

  • Exam 1 covers Introduction (Chapter 1), Atlas A, Chemistry (Chapter 2), Cells (Chapter 3), Histology (Chapter 5).
  • Exam 2 covers Integumentary System (Chapter 6), Bone Tissue (Chapter 7), Joints (Chapter 9).
  • Exam 3 covers Muscle (Chapter 11) and Nervous Tissue (Chapter 12), Spinal Cord/Nerves, Reflexes (Chapter 13)
  • Exam 4 covers Brain and Cranial nerves (Chapter 14), ANS (Chapter 15) and Senses (Chapter 16)

The exams will be proctored through RPNow Software Secure.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"e102e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"e102e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e102e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e102e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"e102e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO12","cl_id":"e102e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e902e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e902e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"e902e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e902e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"e902e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e902e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3902e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961971","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Practical exams","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

There are two laboratory practical exams structured throughout the course with each exam worth 50 points (2 x 50 points = 100 points total representing a weighting of 10% (100/1000)).

  • Exam 1 covers the Language of Anatomy, Scientific Method, Diffusion, Osmosis, Enzymes, Histology, Skeletal
  • Exam 2 covers Muscles, Muscle Physiology, Brain and Cranial Nerves, Reflexes, Senses

The exams will be proctored through RPNow Software Secure.

Weekly assignment consists of:

-          Lecture worksheets (in Connect): 130 points

-          Lecture quizzes (in Connect):  140 points

-          Lab worksheets (in Connect):  70 points

-          Lab quizzes and discussion: 75 points (60 points for quizzes in Connect or Blackboard plus 15 points for discussion topics in Blackboard)

The lecture and lab quizzes contain numerous fill-in-the-blank questions.

The weekly assignment is worth 415 points in total. The assessments in total amount to 1000 points, therefore the weekly assignment has a weighting of 41.5% (415/1000).

The EMG Learn Smart Lab report is worth 20 points (equal to an actual weighting of 2%)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"e102e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e102e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"e902e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e902e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"e902e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e902e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"da02e010dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619d3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory activities","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"5","description":"

"Learn Smart Lab" activities will be conducted in Connect. They cover the following topics: Scientific Method, Diffusion, Osmosis, Enzymes, Muscle Structure & Function, Electromyography (EMG), Reflex Arcs and Reflexes, and Eyes and Vision.

There will also be Hands-on Brain Dissection and Hands-on Eye Dissection using laboratory kits.

The laboratory practical activities are worth 65 points which represents an actual weighting of 6.5%.

contentlets.keywords: asu medicine,human anatomy and physiology,structure and function,major systems,surface anatomy,chemistry,cells,genetics,histology,integumentary,skeletal,joints,muscular,central and peripheral nervous system,autonomic nervous system,sense organs
contentlets.description:
This course covers the study of the structure and function of the human body. Topics including Surface Anatomy, Chemistry, Cells, Genetics, Histology, Integumentary System, Skeletal System, Joints, Muscular System, Central/Peripheral/Autonomic Nervous Systems and Sense Organs. To enhance understanding of concepts, activities used for instruction and assessment of learning include: discussion/presentations; textbook and supplemental readings; individual and group activities/assignments; hands-on dissections and case scenarios. This course also provides valuable professional skills such as laboratory skills, problem-solving, working as part of a team and research and presentation skills. As such, this course prepares students for a wide range of opportunities in public health including: teaching, science communication, exercise physiology, medical sales and health research as a research assistant.

This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.

Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YMED1005 - Introduction to Anatomy and Physiology","description":"

Students will become conversant in the terminology and essential concepts in human anatomy and physiology, and the structure and function of the human body. This is a six units of credit fully online course designed for students interested in health-related professions. The course will acquaint the student with human anatomy, structure, and function, and basic disease concepts. Course concepts will be organized and presented by organ systems, and the laboratory component of the course will emphasize human structure and function. This online course consists of the equivalent of 6 hours of face to face class and laboratory time per week.


This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ba022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961955","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lecture quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Quizzes will cover the required reading and lecture materials. They may be administered on Blackboard.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"36022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961958","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3e022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961956","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3e022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3e022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961958","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"36022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961969","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The Final Exam will also be 50 questions, and you will be allowed 60 minutes for that exam as well. Final Exam is cumulative. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"36022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"36022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961958","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"36022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3e022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961956","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3e022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3e022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961958","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"3e022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961959","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8f022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f396196e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Unit exams","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

There will be 2 unit exams. Students will have 60 minutes to complete each Unit Exam, which will consist of 50 multiple choice questions on topics covered in the assigned reading and lecture.

Both Unit Exams are not cumulative. The Unit Exams will be administered at regular intervals throughout the semester. Students' lowest unit exam score (not their final exam score) may be dropped, if the following applies: a) score for lowest unit exam score is greater than zero (a score of zero that was received due to an unexcused absence cannot be dropped).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"36022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"36022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961958","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"36022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3e022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961956","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3e022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3e022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961958","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"3e022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961959","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f2022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961960","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory activities","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The lab portion of the course accounts for 30% of your overall course grade which will be calculated from the Weekly Lab grade. Each week, the lab grade will be determined by the lab quiz and the Lab Activity Report

Lab Quizzes account for 50% of each weekly lab grade. The quizzes are administered at the beginning of each lab section and cover material from the pre-lab and/or PowerPoint for the day. Makeup sessions will not be granted.

Lab activity Report accounts for 50% of each weekly lab grade.  (Please note the Lab Portion of the course is conducted through a combination of virtual online engagement and practical kit work)

Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YMED1006 - Human Anatomy and Physiology 2","description":"

YMED1006 is the second semester of the study of structure and function of the human body. Topics include: The Blood and Cardiovascular System, Respiratory System, Lymphatic System, Endocrine System, Urinary System, Digestive and Reproductive Systems. To enhance understanding of concepts, activities used for instruction and assessment of learning include: discussion/presentations; textbook and supplemental readings; individual and group activities/assignments; hands-on dissections and case scenarios. This course prepares students for a wide range of opportunities in public health including: teaching, science communication, exercise physiology, medical sales and health research as a research assistant. Students will also be well prepared for further postgraduate education in careers such as medicine, physiotherapy, podiatry and prosthetics and orthotics, or to undertake a PhD to become a research scientist or to follow an academic career.


This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ab022410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ea","name":"Fully online - "},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lecture exams","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

There are four lecture exams structured throughout the course with each exam worth 100 points (4 x 100 points = 400 points total representing a weighting of 40% (400/1000)).

    • Exam 1 covers Blood (Chapter 18), Heart (Chapter 19), Blood Vessels (Chapter 20)
    • Exam 2 covers Respiratory (Chapter 23); Lymphatic (Chapter 22)
    • Exam 3 covers Endocrine System (Chapter 17); Urinary System (Chapter 23); Water, Electrolyte and Acid-Base Balance (Chapter 24)
    • Exam 4 covers Digestive System (Chapter 25); Male & Female Reproductive Systems (Chapters 27 & 28)

      The exams will be proctored through RPNow Software Secure.

      • Exam 2 covers Endocrine; Urinary; Digestive and Reproductive Systems

        The exams will be proctored through RPNow Software Secure.

        "Learn Smart Lab" activities will be conducted in Connect. They cover the following topics: Blood, Heart and ECG, Respiratory system, Endocrine system, Digestive system.

        There will also be Blood Typing Activity, Hands-on Heart Dissection, Hands-on Kidney Dissection using laboratory kits.

        The laboratory practical activities are worth 95 points which represents an actual weighting of 9.5%.

        Weekly assignment consists of:

        -          Lecture worksheets (in Connect): 110 points

        -          Lecture quizzes (in Connect): 100 points

        -          Lab worksheets (in Connect): 80 points

        -          Lab quizzes and discussion: 95 points (85 points for quizzes in Connect or Blackboard plus 10 points for discussion topics in Blackboard)

        The lecture and lab quizzes contain numerous fill-in-the-blank questions.

        The weekly assignment is worth 385 points in total. The assessments in total amount to 1000 points, therefore the weekly assignment has a weighting of 38.5% (385/1000).

contentlets.description:
YMED1006 is the second semester of the study of structure and function of the human body. Topics include: The Blood and Cardiovascular System, Respiratory System, Lymphatic System, Endocrine System, Urinary System, Digestive and Reproductive Systems. To enhance understanding of concepts, activities used for instruction and assessment of learning include: discussion/presentations; textbook and supplemental readings; individual and group activities/assignments; hands-on dissections and case scenarios. This course prepares students for a wide range of opportunities in public health including: teaching, science communication, exercise physiology, medical sales and health research as a research assistant. Students will also be well prepared for further postgraduate education in careers such as medicine, physiotherapy, podiatry and prosthetics and orthotics, or to undertake a PhD to become a research scientist or to follow an academic career.

This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.

Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YMED1008 - Introduction to Global Health","description":"

What makes us sick? How can we promote health? These are big questions that are necessarily global in scope. In an increasingly complex and globalized world, the causative factors in sickness are not just disease agents. They include our evolutionary pasts, and historical decisions, our current natural, social and built environments, how we relate to each other, and what we believe.


This course integrates knowledge from the social and life sciences, including cutting-edge research being done around the world by ASU faculty, to question our most basic assumptions about why we get sick and what we should do about it. It recognizes the need for a trans disciplinary and highly collaborative approach to addressing illness around the world, highlights the critical role of social perspectives in the global promotion of health, and advocates for the importance of health as a social justice issue.


This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.

Book Club Part I and Part II are worth 50 points each (weighting of 13.2%)

Each module (except #7) has a quiz that is designed to check your comprehension of the readings, lectures, and videos (questions are based on all REQUIRED content and students have 60 minutes to complete each quiz). There is also a separate Required Readiness Quiz, which students need to take and score at least an 80% on before beginning the course content. The Required Readiness Quiz is based on the Syllabus and information on the left hand Blackboard menu.

Each quiz is worth 40 points each, therefore the quizzes are worth 40 x 6 = 240 points. There are 760 total possible points to earn in this course, therefore the quizzes carry an actual weighting of 31.6%.

The focus of this course is to provide an overview of the federal/state health policy legislative process, how it is implemented in institutions, and its effect on health science professionals and delivery of services.


This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3d12a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ee","name":"Fully online - "},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group presentation of legislation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Each group will prepare a 10-12 PPT slide presentation of their chosen piece of healthcare legislation, including a slide of references. PPT slides for all groups will be due on 4/11 to the discussion board.  This assignment, worth 30 points will be graded on a group and individual basis. Groups will be assigned 20 points for the PPT presentation. Individuals will be assigned 10 points for their participation and contribution to this assignment throughout the semester.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"b512a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b512a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b512a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bd12a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bd12a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0a12e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961908","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly attendance","assessment_type":{"label":"Attendance","value":"attendance"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"15","description":"

Weekly class attendance. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"b512a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b512a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b512a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bd12a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bd12a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0e12a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Legislative article critique","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Each student will choose and critique an article from a peer-reviewed journal that discusses the legislative topic chosen by the group for the semester. The review should be double spaced (10-12 point font, AMA 10th ed format), and at least 2-3 pages in length not including cover page and reference page. This assignment will be due during finals week.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"b512a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b512a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b512a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bd12a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bd12a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3d12a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Issue Brief","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Groups will choose one piece of health care legislation at the state or federal level that will be the focus of assignments for the entire semester. Each student will write a one-page paper (single-spaced, 10-12 point font, in AMA 10th ed. format) that addresses the health care legislation chosen. Note that the topic must fit within the course objectives.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b512a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bd12a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c612e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961900","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students are to read Antigone and will be required to submit answers to study questions on the day of the in-class discussion prior to class start in the digital drop box.  Please answer each question in at least 300 words.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b512a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b512a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bd12a410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619f0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ce12e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961903","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/YMED3001.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course investigates methods of inquiry in health sciences and techniques for critiquing and interpreting research within the context of evidence-based practice.


This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2612e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619c0","name":"Fully online - "},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Journal entries","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Similar to assignments, all journal entries require application of knowledge gained from the book chapters, slides, and supplemental reading materials prior to developing an entry. Detailed instructions for each entry can be found within the unit tabs.

\n

Students are to prepare four journal entries during the course. Each entry is worth 20 points (20 x 4 = 80 points in total). The journal entries make up 14% of the total grade.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a612e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ae12e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619c0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ae12e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2212e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619c8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Chapter assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be learning critical skills necessary to analyze evidence-based journal articles throughout the semester. The course is not envisioned as “turning the student into a researcher” – it is designed to show students how to USE research in their scope of practice. Students will therefore be responsible for evaluating articles. Each week new techniques necessary to evaluate evidence-based articles will be covered and students will complete assignments based on journal articles.

\n

There will be six chapter assignments structured throughout the course. Each assignment is worth 30 points (30 x 6 = 180 points in total). The assignments comprise 31.6% of the total grade.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a612e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ae12e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619c0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ae12e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2612e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619c3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Syllabus quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"5","description":"

The questions in the quiz will be based on the syllabus content. This quiz will take place in Week 1. It is worth 10 points, representing 1.8% of the total grade (570 points).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a612e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ae12e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619c0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6a12e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619cc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exams","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

There will be 3 exams throughout the semester reviewing information covered in the power point presentations and book chapters. Each exam is worth 100 points; the three exams have a course value of 300 points, representing 52.6% of the total grade.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a612e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ae12e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619c0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ae12e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7212e410dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619d0","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/YMED3002.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.

Students are required to give two narrated Power Points during the course. The first one is a Beginnings introductory activity- students must provide an introduction of self and a key concept for the course as well as practice use of technology. The second one is a Legislative Power Point, designed for students to share information learned from the study of a specific piece of environmentally related legislation.

This course examines the interdependent relationship between the health of the environment and the health of communities. Includes a focus on specific communities, as well as agencies and laws involved in the health of communities.

This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.

This course introduces common co-occurring mental and behavioral health issues related to patients’ chronic medical conditions and evidence-based assessment strategies to address behavioral health needs in primary care and other medical settings.


This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a7122810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a7122810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"af122810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619d8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"af122810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"af122810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"77126810dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961906","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-term exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Multiple-choice exam will cover all materials through the first half of the course and is worth 30 points

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a7122810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"af122810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619d8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7f126810dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961902","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Discussion boards","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

There will be 5 discussion boards worth 4 points each (20 possible points in total).  3 points for initial post, 1 point for response post.

Participation in the written and/or verbal discussion board posts is necessary for success of this class. Discussion board assignments are to facilitate class interaction regarding the weekly topic and questions.  Responses must answer the question, or discuss the topic posed by the instructor in the Discussion Board Question/Topic.  The student is expected to synthesize the content of the readings and other course materials, citing specific sources in their posts. Posts that do not address the question posed by the instructor will not receive credit.

Discussion Board activities begin and end within the designated Weeks/Modules.

To get full credit on the Discussion Board posts and responses, students must complete an initial substantive** post with reference(s) by Friday at 11:59 pm (AZ time) of the corresponding week.  An additional substantive** response must be submitted to at least one classmate’s post by Sunday 11:59 pm (AZ time) of the corresponding week under each designated forum.

** length and quality are important considerations when it comes to participation in discussion board and scavenger hunt posts. Posts/responses are expected to reflect critical thinking. Students must demonstrate that they have synthesized the materials presented in the articles/websites and that they are relating their posts/responses to materials covered in class and/or the greater literature available.  To earn full credit,  students must add something of substance to the discussion -- this consists of new ideas, your perspectives, specific follow-up questions, and relevant references. All posts/responses should integrate the new information with the information previously reviewed in the course.

All posts/responses/comments must be at least 300 words (not including salutations or references). Substantive initial posts include at least one in-text citation of references provided from the course materials.  Response posts to their classmates (due on Sundays at 11:59pm) do not require references, but must be at least 300 words.  Students should proofread posts carefully, as grammar and spelling errors will impact your grade. References must be in APA 6th edition format.

contentlets.keywords: asu medicine,behavioural and mental disorders,behavioural health,mental health,behaviour change,behavioural health care management,counselling,behavioural risk factors
contentlets.description:
This course introduces common co-occurring mental and behavioral health issues related to patients’ chronic medical conditions and evidence-based assessment strategies to address behavioral health needs in primary care and other medical settings.

This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.
contentlets.title: Behavioural and Mental Disorders

This course introduces economics and demonstrates the relevance of economic principles to the study of health care delivery systems and public health. By completing this subject, the student will be prepared for further study of health economics.


This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"04226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a5","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Homework","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

All the homework assignments will be submitted through Blackboard. The due date for each homework assignment will be announced on Blackboard and in class. Homework will be a mix of multiple choice and short answer questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"40226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"40226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"48226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1c226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619b1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Examinations","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

There will be two exams structured during the course, Exam 1 and 2. Each exam is worth 20% (2 x 20% = 40% total). The exams will cover all material covered prior to the date of the exam. The second exam is not cumulative, however students will be highly encouraged to stay current with the assignments and material. The exams will consist of both short answer and multiple choice questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"40226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"40226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"48226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"54226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619b6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research days","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

There will be approximately 4 "research days" scheduled throughout the semester. On these days students will get to participate in different economic scenarios set up in the online discussion spaces that will help their learning and absorption of the material that are discussed in class. Students' grades will depend on their attendance.

\n

The 3 lowest grades across the combined homework and Research Days will be dropped.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"40226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"40226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"48226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c4226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The final exam will be a cumulative exam of all material covered over the semester. Therefore, students will be highly encouraged to stay current with the assignments and material over the 7.5 weeks. The exam will consist of both short answer and multiple choice questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"40226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"40226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"48226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619a6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d0226810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ad","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/YMED3005.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YMED3006 - Comparative Health Systems","description":"

This course introduces students to the principles and practice of health system analysis, the sources and utilisation of information relating to health services, and frameworks for assessing health systems performance. Students examine the historical contexts and legal, economic, social, and political environments within which health care systems operate. Through the comparison of different models of health system funding students will develop an understanding of:


  • What has influenced the development of healthcare systems in different countries;
  • What the advantages and disadvantages of different health system models are, and why;
  • How health systems are financed and managed; and
  • How the performance of a health system is measured.

The course will compare the Australian health system with a range of low, middle and high income countries across the region and the globe.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f822a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f396191f","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Weekly quizzes designed to test students’ understanding of course material covered and their ability to apply it to real-world problems. Questions will consist of multiple-choice, multiple answer, fill-in-the-blank, matching, and/or short written response. Quizzes will give students the opportunity to solidify their learning of concepts covered each week.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f422a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f422a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"fc22a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fc22a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fc22a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7422a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961924","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will make considered and meaningful contributions to three online small group discussion forums. Each forum will be themed and stimulus will be provided. Length: 150-300 words per post

Students will be asked to also submit a short report of 1000 words in which they reflect on one or more of the discussions that they contributed to. The report should outlines the key points or issues that were raised in regards to the allocated topic. The student may use sections of their own contributions to the week’s posts and a critical review of the themes considered the larger group.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f422a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f422a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"fc22a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fc22a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fc22a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7422a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f396192b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will produce a written essay of 1,500 words comparing the structure and performance of the Australian health system with at least one other. The essay will compare the historical context within which each system operates, and analyse the impact differing legal, economic, social, and political environments have had on their performance. Students will formulate context-relevant suggestions for how health system challenges identified can be met.

Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YMED3007 - Environmental and Occupational Health","description":"

This course examines the major environmental health issues facing our global environment in the 21st century, important concepts of environmental health, the range of factors impacting upon global environmental health, key environmental hazards posing risks to human health and safety, and several programmes and policies in place to address environmental health issues. Topics covered include Introduction to Ecological Principles, Population Dynamics, Population Control, the People-Food Predicament, Impacts of Growth on Ecosystems, Environment-related Disease, Toxic Substances, Pests and Pesticides,Food quality, Radiation, the Atmosphere, Air Pollution, Noise Pollution, Water Resources, and Water Pollution.


This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9122a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619aa","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Homework/ study guide assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

There are sixteen (16) homework assignments which will be completed from the study guide booklet that accompanies the textbook. The homework assignments act as study guides for the exams. Students will get credit for turning them in and answering all questions; credit is not based on correct/incorrect answers. However, students are strongly encouraged to do research for answering them correctly, to enhance their capacity to do well on the exams. The correct answers to the questions will not be provided as the answers can be found in the text of the chapters. 

The 16 homework assignments represent 10 points each (16 x 10 = 160 points in total) out of a total of 730 possible points for the course assessment (160/730 = 22% weighting)

Four (4) exams will cover all material presented in lecture (Power Point presentations), assigned readings, and homework/ study guide assignments. Each exam will cover 4 chapters (chapters 1-4, 5-8, 9-12, 13-16) of the prescribed textbook.

The four exams represent 100 points each (4 x 100 = 400 points in total) out of a total of 730 possible points for the course assessment (400/730 = 55% weighting).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"9122a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"9122a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9122a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9122a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9922a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9922a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"9922a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9922a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"9922a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7922a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ea","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Discussion boards","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"5","description":"

There will be two (2) Discussion Boards:

Discussion #1: Class Introductions; one post requirement

Discussion #2: Students will watch a documentary entitled, Climate Refugees. Students will be able to watch the documentary through either:

  • ?Netflix (Netflix.com). Netflix offers a one-month subscription free;
  • ?or, at http://www.snagfilms.com/films/title/climate_refugees for free.

Students will then contribute comments as instructed on the discussion board for this assignment. You are required to submit 2 posts for this discussion: one original post and one post responding to another student’s post.

Discussion #1 (Class Introductions) is assessed as 5 points and Discussion #2(Environmental Refugees) at 15 points representing 20 points in total (20/730 points = 3% weighting)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"9122a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"9122a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9122a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9122a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9922a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9922a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"9922a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9922a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"9922a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a922a810dbbdfc90be4672f5f39619df","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Issue position papers","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

There will be three (3) Issue Position Papers. Throughout the semester, students will be given a total of three(3) articles, each of which presents clashing views on current, significant environmental issues.(Articles will be available via the ASU library’s E-Reserve; more information regarding accessing the articles will be posted in the course). The articles are presented in a yes/no format, each regarding a significant environmental issue in which the authors present opposing views. Students will prepare a paper that summarizes each author's view by listing one author's "yes" talking points and the other author's "no" talking points, i.e., reasons "for" and "against." Students will then take a side, i.e., decide on their own position on the issue ("yes" or "no") and provide reasons "why" for their position. Students must use and cite 2 references (not found in the articles) in support of their position (from journals and/or reputable* web sites). References should be listed in APA style. The part of the paper that presents your position should be 1-page in length, single spaced. Papers will then be submitted via the course's DROPBOX tool. A Position Paper Template is provided for students to use.

*Reputable web sites: The information they provide is based on research and facts, not on fiction,ideological myth and hearsay, and hyped media reports with a political agenda. 

The three issue position papers represent 50 points each (3 x 50 = 150 points) out of a total of 730 possible points (21% weighting).

contentlets.keywords: asu medicine,environmental health,health of communities,local,state,national,and international agencies,environmental issues,organizations and laws involved in environmental health,occupational health,global environmental health,environmental hazards,population dynamics,population control,toxic substances,pests,pesticides,false,food quality,radiation,pollution
contentlets.description:
This course examines the major environmental health issues facing our global environment in the 21st century, important concepts of environmental health, the range of factors impacting upon global environmental health, key environmental hazards posing risks to human health and safety, and several programmes and policies in place to address environmental health issues. Topics covered include Introduction to Ecological Principles, Population Dynamics, Population Control, the People-Food Predicament, Impacts of Growth on Ecosystems, Environment-related Disease, Toxic Substances, Pests and Pesticides,Food quality, Radiation, the Atmosphere, Air Pollution, Noise Pollution, Water Resources, and Water Pollution.

This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU) in the online mode only as part of the PLuS Alliance Bachelor of International Public Health degree.
contentlets.title: Environmental and Occupational Health

Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YMED5000 - Integrated Emergency Management","description":"

From antiquity disasters and emergencies have plagued mankind. Effective preparation for and management of these events make it possible to mitigate the consequences.


This course critically assesses the foundations and strategies of emergency management. It is designed to expand the student's thinking, analysis and ability to communicate within the world of emergency management.


Focal issues include the four phases of emergency management: mitigation, preparedness, response and recovery.  An analysis of past disasters will be used to discuss their impacts on policy formation and contemporary strategies. The role, duties, and importance of the Emergency Manager as it relates to FEMA's all­ hazards approach will be discussed throughout the course.


This courses will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PluS Alliance. The course will be taught fully online.

contentlets.keywords: asu medicine,integrated emergency management,emergency management,disasters,emergency strategy,emergency
contentlets.description:
From antiquity disasters and emergencies have plagued mankind. Effective preparation for and management of these events make it possible to mitigate the consequences.

This course critically assesses the foundations and strategies of emergency management. It is designed to expand the student's thinking, analysis and ability to communicate within the world of emergency management.

Focal issues include the four phases of emergency management: mitigation, preparedness, response and recovery.  An analysis of past disasters will be used to discuss their impacts on policy formation and contemporary strategies. The role, duties, and importance of the Emergency Manager as it relates to FEMA's all­ hazards approach will be discussed throughout the course.

This courses will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PluS Alliance. The course will be taught fully online.
contentlets.title: Integrated Emergency Management

This course provides the student with fundamentals of emergency response to suspected terrorist events. This is a historical perspective of terrorist activities and methods by which responders can identify and protect themselves, and the public, from these types of threats. Coordination of responding agencies is also be explored.


This courses will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PluS Alliance. The course will be taught fully online.

contentlets.keywords: asu medicine,homeland security,emergency response,terrorism
contentlets.description:
This course provides the student with fundamentals of emergency response to suspected terrorist events. This is a historical perspective of terrorist activities and methods by which responders can identify and protect themselves, and the public, from these types of threats. Coordination of responding agencies is also be explored.

This courses will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PluS Alliance. The course will be taught fully online.
contentlets.title: Homeland Security

Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YMED5002 - Hazards Governance","description":"

This course examines how hazards are managed by both community and national-level policymaking and administrative systems, with a particular focus on understanding how policies and management practices are related to risk reduction and resilience capacity promotion. The course explores what governance means in practice and presents existing research, including policy reports, cases studies and quantitative analyses of community-level and national-level hazards management programs and related public policies—and how their integration is relevant to hazards governance. There is an emphasis on understanding the nature of public goods production processes, including how inter-sector integration (i.e. between, public, private and nonprofit organizations) and extant community vulnerability profiles matter to the specific risk reduction efforts, and what those same efforts yield in terms of aggregate community resilience outcomes.


This courses will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PluS Alliance. The course will be taught fully online.

contentlets.keywords: asu medicine,hazards,hazards governance,risk reduction,governance,risk management,policy,resilience promotion
contentlets.description:
This course examines how hazards are managed by both community and national-level policymaking and administrative systems, with a particular focus on understanding how policies and management practices are related to risk reduction and resilience capacity promotion. The course explores what governance means in practice and presents existing research, including policy reports, cases studies and quantitative analyses of community-level and national-level hazards management programs and related public policies—and how their integration is relevant to hazards governance. There is an emphasis on understanding the nature of public goods production processes, including how inter-sector integration (i.e. between, public, private and nonprofit organizations) and extant community vulnerability profiles matter to the specific risk reduction efforts, and what those same efforts yield in terms of aggregate community resilience outcomes.

This courses will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PluS Alliance. The course will be taught fully online.
contentlets.title: Hazards Governance

In this course we will explore public management in theory and practice. A discussion of public management involves the environment, individuals, politics, and organizations that implement public policy. This course emphasizes both substantive (theory) and skill (practice) development. The substance is the vast literature subsumed under the rubric of public management and organizational theory. The skills are those associated with the practice of understanding and diagnosing public management as well as further developing research and analytical skills. This course will encourage students to bring their experiences to the course thereby extending, challenging, and offering new perspectives resulting in a more in-depth understanding of public management. 


This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU), and will be offered to UNSW students. The course will be offered solely online, and utilise the internationally renowned online educational systems of ASU.

This course provides theory and application of both computer and internet-based programs in emergency management, including the use of various emergency modeling programs. The course will also introduce you to potential applications of information technology to the field of emergency management in general. My intent with this course is to provide a basic understanding and, when possible, hands-on experience with these technologies. The emphasis is on understanding and application, rather than technical ability.


The applications and technologies we will utilize and discuss are pertinent to emergency management, firefighting, law enforcement, emergency medical services, public health, hazardous materials and natural disaster response, and/or homeland security. Some will even be pertinent to your personal life. Topics covered in this course will include use of geographic information systems (GIS), digital hazard modeling, alert and warning systems, communications technologies, web-based situational awareness programs, and social media.


This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU), and will be offered to UNSW students. The course will be offered solely online, and utilise the internationally renowned online educational systems of ASU.

contentlets.description:
This course provides theory and application of both computer and internet-based programs in emergency management, including the use of various emergency modeling programs. The course will also introduce you to potential applications of information technology to the field of emergency management in general. My intent with this course is to provide a basic understanding and, when possible, hands-on experience with these technologies. The emphasis is on understanding and application, rather than technical ability.

The applications and technologies we will utilize and discuss are pertinent to emergency management, firefighting, law enforcement, emergency medical services, public health, hazardous materials and natural disaster response, and/or homeland security. Some will even be pertinent to your personal life. Topics covered in this course will include use of geographic information systems (GIS), digital hazard modeling, alert and warning systems, communications technologies, web-based situational awareness programs, and social media.

This course is being taught by Arizona State University (ASU), and will be offered to UNSW students. The course will be offered solely online, and utilise the internationally renowned online educational systems of ASU.

Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YMED5005 - Community Resilience and Recovery","description":"

This course examines community resilience from a systems perspective, embracing governments, private, nonprofit, and civic roles.  Presents research, case studies, and strategies for policy planning and implementation. The course also provides an understanding of how community members respond to the need to prepare for, endure, and recover from disasters; and the ability to utilize multiple communication methods to help community members before, during, and after these emergencies. 


This courses will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PluS Alliance. The course will be taught fully online.

contentlets.keywords: asu medicine,community resilience,community recovery,community studies,case studies,policy,disasters,disaster management,emergency management
contentlets.description:
This course examines community resilience from a systems perspective, embracing governments, private, nonprofit, and civic roles.  Presents research, case studies, and strategies for policy planning and implementation. The course also provides an understanding of how community members respond to the need to prepare for, endure, and recover from disasters; and the ability to utilize multiple communication methods to help community members before, during, and after these emergencies. 

This courses will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PluS Alliance. The course will be taught fully online.
contentlets.title: Community Resilience and Recovery

Interoperability for Emergency Managers enables student understanding of the multiple technologies and skills utilized by emergency managers to enhance successful coordination and communication between all levels of emergency managers and responders during emergency mitigation, prevention, preparedness, response and recovery operations.


This courses will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PluS Alliance. The course will be taught fully online.

contentlets.keywords: asu medicine,emergency management,interoperability for managers,technologies,emergency mitigation,recovery operations,emergency co-ordination,emergency,management
contentlets.description:
Interoperability for Emergency Managers enables student understanding of the multiple technologies and skills utilized by emergency managers to enhance successful coordination and communication between all levels of emergency managers and responders during emergency mitigation, prevention, preparedness, response and recovery operations.

This courses will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PluS Alliance. The course will be taught fully online.
contentlets.title: Interoperability for Emergency Managers

Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YMED5007 - Critical Incident Stress Management","description":"

This course will incorporate the most recent research on the effects of stress and trauma by introducing students to a comprehensive understanding of the neurophysiology of stress and trauma. Since the body’s physiology as well as the psychology of the individual is each uniquely affected by stressful and traumatic events, the interface of cognitive-based and body-based practices is considered essential for the complete resolution of stress and trauma reactions. The topics of stress, trauma, vicarious trauma and mass trauma will be explored as it is experienced by the individual and large populations. This course combines experiential class activities, evidenced based readings and research so students can conceptualize as well as practice these skills so they can track their quality of health through multiple activities such as heart rate monitoring, sleep habits, clarity of focus and mindfulness practice activities.


This courses will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PluS Alliance. The course will be taught fully online.

This course provides an introduction to quantitative approaches to data analysis from descriptive and inferential perspectives. Students will be exposed to key foundational elements of quantitative analyses necessary to develop proficiencies to become consumers of and contributors of research. Students will learn to select appropriate statistical procedures, calculate statistics, and interpret statistical tests and graphics.


This courses will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PluS Alliance. The course will be taught fully online.

contentlets.keywords: asu medicine,applied data analysis,data,anaylsis,quantitative analysis,statistics
contentlets.description:
This course provides an introduction to quantitative approaches to data analysis from descriptive and inferential perspectives. Students will be exposed to key foundational elements of quantitative analyses necessary to develop proficiencies to become consumers of and contributors of research. Students will learn to select appropriate statistical procedures, calculate statistics, and interpret statistical tests and graphics.

This courses will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PluS Alliance. The course will be taught fully online.
contentlets.title: Applied Data Analysis in Criminal Justice

The overall goal of this course is to develop knowledge and expertise in the practice of evaluating public or nonprofit sector programs, policies and other agency actions—especially as applicable in the area of emergency management and homeland security issues . The course will do so specifically by developing students’ knowledge and skill in identifying appropriate research designs for particular evaluation problems, knowledge, skill and ability in focusing evaluation reports based on project objectives, refinement of skill and ability in empirical analysis, and in the development of skill and ability in appropriately characterizing and presenting empirical those data gathered for an assessment project. In sum, this course should be understood as an opportunity to learn more about conducting evaluative research in a way that is relevant to solving public and nonprofit sector management challenges.


This courses will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PluS Alliance. The course will be taught fully online.
